study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of group reminiscence therapy on reducing death anxiety and improving adaptation to old age in the elderly.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy significantly reduced death anxiety and improved adaptation to old age in the intervention group, with effects persisting 30 days post-intervention, while no significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 32 elderly individuals (16 intervention, 16 control)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a mindfulness-based rehabilitation program, including reminiscence activities, could improve cognitive and behavioral outcomes in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in MoCA global scores, memory sub-scale scores, and BDI-II cognitive and affective factors in the experimental group (MILC-tr) compared to the usual structured program. The results suggest mindfulness-based rehabilitation, including reminiscence therapy, may be effective for PD and MCI patients.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a reminiscence therapy-involved care program (RTICP) could improve cognitive functions, anxiety, depression, patient satisfaction, and survival in elderly lung cancer patients.
results_summary: RTICP improved cognitive function (MMSE) and patient satisfaction, reduced anxiety (HADS-A) at multiple time points, and alleviated depression (HADS-D) at later stages, but did not affect depression rates, disease-free survival, or overall survival compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Elderly post-operative lung cancer patients (n = 138, aged not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically identify, synthesize, and describe the research evidence and quality of systematic reviews related to reminiscence interventions for older people using an evidence-mapping approach.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy showed beneficial or potentially beneficial effects in 92.8% of the included studies, particularly for mental and psychological problems, quality of life, and positive psychology outcomes. However, the methodological quality of most systematic reviews was low or critically low, indicating a need for higher-quality evidence and standardized protocols.
population_specificity: Older adults, including those with depression, dementia, and general older populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of instrumental reminiscence therapy based on Roy's adaptation model on adaptation, life satisfaction, and happiness in older people.
results_summary: The study found that instrumental reminiscence therapy significantly increased adaptation, life satisfaction, and happiness in older people, with posttest scores significantly higher than pretest scores and a significant difference between intervention and control groups.
population_specificity: Older people residing in two nursing homes in Northern Cyprus.
study_duration: April to June 2021 (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of reminiscence therapy (RT) on communicative ability, particularly focusing on language features, in people with dementia (PWD).
results_summary: RT significantly improved informative/semantic linguistic ability (measured by correct information units and Holden Communication Scale scores) but did not affect the amount of discourse (syllable count). The effects were most notable in the first two weeks of intervention.
population_specificity: Women with dementia registered in a day-care center.
effective_dosage: Not specified (RT sessions using digital material or storytelling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of reminiscence therapy on anxiety, depression, and quality of life in elderly patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy significantly reduced anxiety scores at 9 and 12 months and improved global health status at 6 and 12 months compared to the control group. Depression scores also declined at 9 and 12 months, though the proportion of patients with depression did not differ significantly.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) post-resection (N=106).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of group reminiscence therapy (RT) in reducing anxiety and depressive symptoms in acutely hospitalized older patients.
results_summary: The study found that RT significantly reduced the proportion of patients with moderate-severe anxiety (13.4% vs. 32.1%) and depressive symptoms (19.5% vs. 49.1%) compared to usual care. The intervention was independently associated with benefits on anxiety and depression levels, though absolute changes in scores were relatively small.
population_specificity: Acutely hospitalized older patients without severe cognitive impairment, mobility issues, or clinical/hemodynamic instability.
effective_dosage: Multi-task daily group session of reminiscence activities (specific duration per session not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of hospitalization (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Reminiscence Therapy (RT) on cognition, depression, and quality of life in elderly patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD) through a synthesis of randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
results_summary: RT, administered individually or in group sessions at least once weekly for 30-35 minutes over 12 weeks, was found effective in improving global cognition, reducing depression, and enhancing specific aspects of quality of life in elderly AD patients. However, generalizability is limited due to the small number of RCTs and lack of long-term follow-up.
population_specificity: Elderly people with Alzheimer's disease (AD).
effective_dosage: 30-35 minutes per session, at least once weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a reminiscence therapy-based care program (RTCP + UC) on anxiety, depression, quality of life, and survival in surgical prostate cancer patients.
results_summary: RTCP + UC reduced anxiety and depression scores at specific time points, improved global health status scores, but had no effect on disease-free survival or overall survival. It did not influence function or symptom scores at any time point.
population_specificity: 108 surgical prostate cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of reminiscence therapy plus usual care (RTUC) versus usual care (UC) alone on cognitive function, anxiety, and depression in recurrent acute ischemic stroke (AIS) patients.
results_summary: RTUC improved cognitive function (higher MMSE scores at 6 and 12 months) and reduced anxiety (lower HADS-anxiety scores at 9 and 12 months) compared to UC. It also decreased depression scores at 12 months, though depression rates and severity did not differ significantly between groups.
population_specificity: Recurrent acute ischemic stroke (AIS) patients (N=160).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a proximity-aware technology system (Memento) could facilitate Reminiscence Therapy by helping caregivers connect residents with their personal stories, thereby improving engagement and well-being.
results_summary: Memento successfully enabled caregivers to initiate spontaneous reminiscences with residents, which residents found highly enjoyable, leading to improved self-confidence and well-being. The technology effectively bridged the gap between residents' histories and their surroundings, making Reminiscence Therapy more accessible in daily care practices.
population_specificity: Older adults living with dementia in care homes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an AI-based computer application that recreates personalized Reminiscence Therapy (RT) using facial expression analysis and reinforcement learning to dynamically guide the therapy in real time.
results_summary: The study found high user satisfaction and an increase in positive emotions among participants, while negative emotions remained low. The results suggest that the AI-assisted RT was effective in enhancing emotional well-being.
population_specificity: Seniors at five senior centers in Barcelona and Portugal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of reminiscence therapy on cognitive function, mood, and overall well-being in people with dementia.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy improved cognitive function and quality of life while reducing depression and neuropsychiatric symptoms in people with dementia. The study suggests it is a useful non-pharmacological intervention for dementia care in long-term facilities.
population_specificity: People with dementia living in nursing homes or other long-term care facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of using EEG signals for automatic emotion recognition during Reminiscence Therapy in older people.
results_summary: The study found that Bi-LSTM models achieved high accuracy (95.8%) in classifying positive and negative emotions from EEG signals during Reminiscence Therapy, demonstrating the feasibility of EEG-based emotion recognition without multimodal signals.
population_specificity: Eleven older people (mean age 71.25) and seven young people (mean age 22.4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a brief, positive-memory version of cognitive-reminiscence therapy (CRT) on psychological resources and mental well-being in young adults.
results_summary: CRT significantly improved psychological resources (self-esteem, self-efficacy, meaning in life, optimism) and mental well-being (reduced depression, anxiety, stress symptoms) post-intervention and at follow-up, with moderate to large effect sizes. Hypotheses about change processes (e.g., reduced automatic negative thoughts) were supported.
population_specificity: Young adults (N=62, mean age 24.6, 71% female).
study_duration: Short-term (three sessions, follow-up duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of reminiscence therapy (RT) in reducing depression, improving autobiographical memory, and enhancing quality of life in individuals with mild to moderate dementia in long-term care facilities.
results_summary: RT showed effectiveness in reducing depression and improving autobiographical memory, though results were inconsistent. A significant improvement in quality of life was observed, but meta-analysis did not find statistically significant effects on depression or autobiographical memory scores.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild to moderate dementia in long-term care facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether individual Reminiscence Therapy (RT) could improve cognitive function, memory, executive functions, emotional status, and quality of life in older adults with neurocognitive disorders receiving social care.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the intervention group receiving RT and the control group, though contextual factors like the COVID-19 pandemic and therapist heterogeneity may have influenced outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults with neurocognitive disorders receiving social care and support services in the Azores archipelago.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of using digital touch screen technology to deliver Reminiscence Therapy (RT) among people with dementia in Jordanian care homes and to compare pre- and post-intervention outcomes.
results_summary: The study found a positive, statistically significant, and clinically relevant difference in all outcome measures after RT sessions, with participants reporting enhanced communication and cognitive abilities. The intervention was well-accepted, with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: People with dementia living in Jordanian care homes (n=60).
effective_dosage: 10 supported RT sessions of up to 1 hour each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of individual reminiscence therapy (iRT) in improving cognitive functioning, mood, and quality of life in older adults with neurocognitive disorders (NCD) and to identify predictors of positive intervention responses.
results_summary: The iRT intervention showed significant improvements in cognition and memory, with higher response rates compared to the control group. Participants with worse executive dysfunction, mood, and quality of life at baseline benefited the most from the intervention for those respective outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adult residents with neurocognitive disorders (NCD) from residential facilities across Portugal.
effective_dosage: Biweekly sessions (26 sessions total over 13 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of reminiscence therapy involved care (RTIC) compared to usual care (UC) on anxiety, depression, quality of life (QoL), and survival in postoperative cervical cancer patients.
results_summary: RTIC reduced anxiety (partly) and depression, and improved QoL in postoperative cervical cancer patients, particularly in those aged ≥50 years, but showed no effect on symptom scores or overall survival.
population_specificity: Postoperative cervical cancer patients (N=152, randomized into RTIC and UC groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (routine care plus reminiscence therapy for the RTIC group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether using head-mounted displays (HMDs) for reminiscence therapy improves apathy symptoms compared to laptop-based reminiscence therapy or usual care in older adults living in residential aged care.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in apathy, cognition, or depression outcomes between the VR and laptop groups or between the intervention groups and the passive control group. However, participants enjoyed the reminiscence process and preferred VR over flat-screen content, with negligible side effects from HMD use.
population_specificity: Older adults living in residential aged care facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of different types of old photos on the fluency of conversation and emotional outcomes between older people and younger volunteers during Reminiscence Therapy.
results_summary: The study found that photo types had little effect on older people, with conversations generally being pleasant, but their pleasantness increased when using photos they wanted to discuss. Young people's attention to the topic positively influenced older people's pleasure in conversation, while inappropriate photo selection significantly reduced younger volunteers' engagement.
population_specificity: Older people in Japan experiencing social isolation and younger volunteers assisting in Reminiscence Therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and review existing evidence on the effect of reminiscence therapy on depression in older adults.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy significantly alleviated depressive symptoms in older adults, particularly those with chronic illness or on antidepressants, and improved secondary outcomes like life satisfaction. Group therapy was more cost-effective than individual therapy, and structured therapy was more replicable and user-friendly.
population_specificity: Older adults, particularly those with depression, chronic illness, or on antidepressants, with a noted stronger effect in older women and those with severe depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of reminiscence therapy on anxiety, depression, quality of life, and survival in postoperative gastric cancer patients.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy reduced anxiety scores and rates at later time points (M6, M9, M12) and improved global health status at M12, but did not affect depression scores, function scores, or survival outcomes. Subgroup analyses suggested stronger effects in patients aged ≤60 years and male patients.
population_specificity: Postoperative gastric cancer patients (N=160, randomized 1:1 into therapy and control groups).
study_duration: Evaluations at baseline, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of group Reminiscence Therapy (RT) on cognition, depressive symptoms, and quality of life in older adults in nursing homes.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant improvements in cognitive performance, depressive symptoms, or quality of life among participants, though stabilization of these outcomes was noted as clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 83.32±7.76) in nursing homes without severe cognitive impairment.
study_duration: Core Program and Follow-up Program (total duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a conversational system for delivering personalized reminiscence therapy to Alzheimer's patients.
results_summary: The system successfully personalized reminiscence therapy based on patient information, as evaluated by 11 care-related individuals (caregivers and professionals). The therapy was deemed effective in stimulating autobiographical episodic memory.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease and their caregivers/healthcare providers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose a theoretical model (SEED model) to understand the functions of music in reminiscence therapy and its potential to improve the wellbeing of older people.
results_summary: The study proposed that music-assisted reminiscence therapy helps summon autobiographical memories, evoke emotional reactions, elicit physiological responses, and define identity, with evidence supporting these functions. The SEED model provides a framework for future research to test these benefits.
population_specificity: Older people

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of group reminiscence therapy combined with physical exercise in improving spiritual well-being and mental health among elderly individuals post-COVID-19 outbreak.
results_summary: The study found that after 8 weeks, the experimental group showed significantly lower loneliness scores and higher spiritual well-being and resilience scores compared to the control group, with statistically significant differences (P<0.05).
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (n=130) from communities in Xiangtan City and Changsha City, China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (group reminiscence therapy combined with physical exercise, 8-week intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of individual reminiscence therapy on adaptation difficulties in elderly individuals during home visits.
results_summary: The study found that reminiscence therapy significantly decreased adaptation difficulties in the intervention group, as measured by the ASADE scale, while the control group showed increased difficulties. The NOSGER scores also indicated improvements, though the control group's increase was higher.
population_specificity: 65 elderly individuals living in Isparta, Turkey.
effective_dosage: Once a week for eight weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether group reminiscence therapy based on Chinese traditional festival activities (CTFA-GRT) could reduce loneliness and perceived stress in rural older adults living alone in China.
results_summary: The study found that CTFA-GRT significantly decreased perceived stress and loneliness in the intervention group, with effects lasting three months post-intervention. The results were statistically significant (P < 0.01) for both outcomes.
population_specificity: Rural Chinese older adults (aged 65.70 ± 3.69 years) living alone.
effective_dosage: Not specified (group reminiscence therapy sessions over eight months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of reminiscence therapy-involved care (RTC) on anxiety, depression, quality of life, and survival in colorectal cancer (CRC) patients.
results_summary: RTC reduced anxiety and depression scores, improved quality of life, and showed a non-significant trend toward improved survival in CRC patients, with more pronounced effects in older patients and those with advanced disease stages.
population_specificity: 210 post-resection colorectal cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of reminiscence therapy on cognitive impairment, anxiety, depression, and disease recurrence in acute ischemic stroke (AIS) patients.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy improved cognitive function (higher MMSE scores at M9 and M12) and reduced depression (lower SDS scores at M9 and M12), but had no effect on recurrence-free survival (RFS). Anxiety reduction was inconsistent, with lower SAS scores at M12 but no difference in HADS-anxiety scores.
population_specificity: 216 first-ever acute ischemic stroke (AIS) patients.
study_duration: 12 months (with follow-up to 36 months for RFS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of reminiscence therapy-based care (RTBC) on anxiety, depression, patient satisfaction, and survival benefit in glioma patients after tumor resection.
results_summary: The RTBC program significantly reduced anxiety and depression levels, decreased the proportion of anxious and depressed patients, and improved patient satisfaction compared to control care. While there was a trend toward increased overall survival in the RTBC group, it was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Glioma patients post-tumor resection (N=150, randomized into RTBC and control groups).

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of a 13-week individual reminiscence therapy intervention on cognition, memory, executive function, mood, and quality of life in people with Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in global cognition, memory, and quality of life with medium effect sizes, a small effect on executive function, and no effect on depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: 148 people with probable Alzheimer's disease or vascular dementia attending 23 Portuguese care and support institutions for older adults.
effective_dosage: 26 individual RT sessions, twice a week for 13 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a reminiscence therapy-based care program (RTCP) on anxiety, depression, quality of life, and survival in post-operative non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients.
results_summary: RTCP reduced anxiety and depression scores, improved quality of life (global health status and functions), but did not affect survival outcomes compared to the control care program.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed post-operative non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 13-week individual reminiscence therapy intervention in improving cognitive function, memory, executive function, mood, and quality of life in people with neurocognitive disorders.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in cognitive function (MMSE), memory (MAT), and quality of life (QoL-AD) compared to the control group, with non-significant improvements in executive function (FAB) and mood (GDS-15).
population_specificity: People with neurocognitive disorders attending 24 care and support services for older adults in Portugal.
effective_dosage: 26 individual RT sessions, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the components, delivery methods, theoretical framework, and consistency of reminiscence therapy for dementia.
results_summary: The review identified 13 components of reminiscence therapy, with "memory triggers" and "themes" being the most common but inconsistently beneficial. The therapy lacked a clear theoretical framework, standardized delivery, and consistency in facilitator training, though some components like "life stages" and "family-only sessions" showed promise.
population_specificity: People with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits of a reminiscence therapy-based care (RTBC) program on cognitive impairment restoration and anxiety/depression reduction in acute ischemic stroke (AIS) patients.
results_summary: RTBC improved cognitive function (MMSE and MoCA scores), reduced anxiety (SAS scores), and showed some reduction in depression (SDS scores), though not all measures were statistically significant. Patients also reported higher satisfaction with RTBC compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 130 acute ischemic stroke (AIS) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of digital reminiscence therapy (RT) compared to conventional RT and develop a strategy for designing larger randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
results_summary: Digital RT significantly decreased depression and increased engagement compared to the control group, but no significant differences were found in cognition or behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia (BPSD).
population_specificity: 49 people with dementia (PWD) from nine daycare centers in Korea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether group reminiscence therapy could improve spoken discourse in older adults with mild cognitive impairment or dementia, and whether these changes generalized to everyday communication.
results_summary: Two participants with mild cognitive impairment showed significant improvements in macrostructure and richness of nostalgic recounts, with some generalization to everyday discourse. No significant improvements were observed in cognition or quality of life for any participant.
population_specificity: Four older females (mean age 87) with mild (n=2) or major (n=2) neurocognitive impairment living in a residential aged care facility.
effective_dosage: Eight one-hour group reminiscence therapy sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of reminiscence therapy on alleviating agitated behaviors in older adults with dementia.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy showed a clear and immediate effect on decreasing agitated behavior, but no significant and sustained effect was observed post-intervention. The therapy did not reach statistically significant implications compared to the comparison group.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia recruited from two dementia care centers in central and northern Taiwan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether group reminiscence therapy could improve depression and meaning of life among elderly institutionalized veterans.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvement in overall life satisfaction and reductions in depressive symptoms compared to the control group after 8 weeks of reminiscence therapy.
population_specificity: Elderly institutionalized veterans in two veteran homes in southern Taiwan.
effective_dosage: Not specified (group reminiscence therapy sessions for 8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a standardized method for administering reminiscence therapy to older adults with Alzheimer's disease and evaluate its effectiveness.
results_summary: The study found reminiscence therapy effective in improving cognition, depression, activities of daily living, and quality of life in older adults with Alzheimer's disease, particularly when conducted regularly in small groups using personalized stimuli like photographs, videos, and music.
population_specificity: Older adults with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer's disease.
effective_dosage: Conducted for an average of 45 minutes per session in small groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of reminiscence therapy (RT) on people living with dementia by comparing it with no treatment or non-specific activities.
results_summary: The study found some evidence that RT can improve quality of life, cognition, communication, and possibly mood in people with dementia, though all benefits were small. Further research is needed to identify who benefits most from specific types of RT.
population_specificity: People living with dementia.

study_goal: To examine the effect of reminiscence therapy on reducing caregiving burden and enhancing positive feelings and hope in spousal caregivers of elderly patients with advanced cancer.
results_summary: The experimental group showed a significant reduction in caregiving burden and higher levels of positive feelings and hope compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Spousal caregivers of elderly patients with advanced cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of group reminiscence therapy on cognitive function, depression, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and activities of daily living in patients with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer disease.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in depressive and neuropsychiatric symptoms in the intervention group compared to controls, with the greatest effects observed at 12 and 24 weeks post-treatment. No significant improvements in cognitive function or activities of daily living were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer disease recruited from Beijing Geriatric Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of reminiscence therapy on depressive symptoms in older adults with dementia through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study found that reminiscence therapy significantly reduced depressive symptoms in older adults with dementia, with an overall effect size of -0.62. Greater effects were observed in individuals under 80, those with less severe disease, and sessions lasting less than 40 minutes.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (therapy session duration mentioned as less than 40 minutes for greater effect).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether old public photos could evoke autobiographical memories in elderly women and compare brain-activation responses between those with depressive symptoms and normal controls.
results_summary: Old public photos effectively evoked autobiographical memories, with high-DOR photos showing significant brain activation differences between groups. Depressive symptoms were associated with decreased activation in several brain regions during reminiscence.
population_specificity: Elderly women (n=34) with depressive symptoms (n=16) and normal controls (n=18) from urban communities in Southwest China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of reminiscence therapy on depression, quality of life, and behavioral and psychological symptoms in people with dementia.
results_summary: Reminiscence therapy significantly reduced depression (moderate effect size), improved quality of life, and decreased behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia compared to the control group.
population_specificity: People with dementia (PWD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short- and long-term effects of group reminiscence therapy on agitated symptoms and quality of life (QOL) in individuals with dementia.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in overall agitated behavior, but verbally aggressive behavior, intentional falling, hoarding, and akathisia decreased significantly in the short term. Participation in group reminiscence therapy significantly improved QOL across time periods for individuals with dementia.
population_specificity: 43 residents with dementia.
effective_dosage: 50-minute group reminiscence therapy session once per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of functional resistance training (FRT) as a preventive measure against deconditioning in hospitalized inpatients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in muscle strength, grip strength, lower limb function (30STS), and overall mobility (DEMMI) post-FRT, with high patient engagement. Patients with lower engagement showed a 20% reduction in outcomes, indicating deconditioning without FRT.
population_specificity: Inpatients aged 65+ admitted to medical or orthopaedic wards, able to follow instructions, not requiring baseline hoisting, and medically fit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of protein source (animal vs. plant) and resistance exercise training (RET) on muscle anabolism and metabolic health in middle-to-older aged adults.
results_summary: RET significantly increased daily integrated myofibrillar protein synthesis (iMyoPS) rates in both legs, regardless of protein source. The study found no differences in muscle architecture, strength, metabolic rate, or renal function between protein sources, but plant protein reduced non-HDL cholesterol.
population_specificity: Middle-to-older aged adults (50-70 years old).
effective_dosage: 1.0g·kg BM-1·day-1 of protein from either animal (whey) or plant (pea) sources.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether different types of blood flow restriction (BFR) cuffs (narrow-elastic vs. wide-rigid) produce distinct vascular adaptations during resistance training.
results_summary: Both cuff types increased muscle strength, but narrow-elastic cuffs improved vascular function (increased flow-mediated dilation), while wide-rigid cuffs did not. The difference was linked to higher retrograde shear rates induced by wide-rigid cuffs.
population_specificity: Twenty-six young, healthy participants.
effective_dosage: Not specified (supervised BFR training during upper-body resistance exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a 16-week high-speed resistance training (HSRT) program on heart rate variability (HRV) indices and arterial stiffness in independent older adults.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in mean RR, systolic blood pressure, and pulse pressure, indicating favorable changes in parasympathetic activity and reduced arterial stiffness. The control group exhibited within-group increases in stress index, sample entropy, and DFA α1, but no such improvements were seen in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Independent older adults (N = 79, intervention group = 40, control group = 39).
effective_dosage: 5-6 exercises, 2-3 sets, 6-10 repetitions, 3 times weekly, lasting 60-70 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of an 8-week resistance training program using outdoor fitness equipment on sagittal spine disposition and pelvic tilt in middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The training group showed significant reductions in all sagittal spine curvatures and pelvic tilt in the standing position, while the control group only reduced pelvic tilt. In the sitting position, only the training group exhibited a significant decrease in lumbar lordosis.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults (n=128)
effective_dosage: 2 weekly sessions of one-hour resistance circuit training

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of resistance training with supplemental dietary protein on inflammatory changes during adjuvant chemotherapy in colon cancer patients and whether baseline or changes in inflammatory markers were associated with treatment adherence (RDI) or body composition.
results_summary: Resistance training did not significantly alter inflammatory markers compared to usual care. Higher baseline inflammatory markers were associated with better treatment adherence (RDI >70%) and higher baseline body composition measures (BMI, lean mass, fat mass).
population_specificity: 174 patients with colon cancer undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy.
study_duration: Duration of adjuvant chemotherapy (exact length not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 16-week progressive resistance training intervention on cardiovascular risk factors in individuals with secondary progressive multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that progressive resistance training did not produce statistically significant or clinically relevant changes in cardiovascular risk factors, despite improving muscle strength. Natural fluctuations in these factors during the extended baseline period were small.
population_specificity: 30 individuals with secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (mean age 54 years; 67% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 10 weeks of resistance training differentially alters gut microbiome composition, short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), and gastrointestinal integrity markers in younger versus older adults.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training increased lean body mass and muscle thickness equally in both age groups but had no significant effects on gut microbiome diversity, SCFAs, or gastrointestinal integrity markers. No correlations were observed between muscle mass changes and microbiome or SCFA changes.
population_specificity: Untrained younger (22 ± 2 years) and older (58 ± 8 years) adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a low-volume, remotely supervised resistance training protocol on physical frailty, sarcopenia prevalence, and fall risk among frail older adults in daycare centers.
results_summary: The study found that low-volume resistance training preserved handgrip strength and sit-to-stand performance, improved relative muscle power, and reduced exhaustion, physical inactivity, sarcopenia prevalence, and fall frequency, though frailty prevalence showed only a decreasing trend.
population_specificity: Frail older adults attending daycare centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different ranges of loads (50-85% 1RM, 55-75% 1RM, and 60-70% 1RM) on physical performance using velocity-based resistance training.
results_summary: Greater ranges of loads (e.g., 50-85% 1RM) resulted in greater strength gains across the load-velocity spectrum, while smaller ranges (e.g., 60-70% 1RM) showed significant improvements in high-velocity actions like sprinting. All groups saw increases in 1RM, average velocity, and countermovement jump height.
population_specificity: 38 men (age: 23.3 ± 3.6 years, body mass: 76.5 ± 8.3 kg, height: 1.77 ± 0.04 m)
effective_dosage: All groups trained with similar mean relative intensity (65% 1RM) and total volume (240 repetitions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of training to failure (FAIL) versus submaximal effort (2-RIR) on muscle hypertrophy, strength, power, endurance, and RIR estimation accuracy in resistance-trained individuals.
results_summary: Both FAIL and 2-RIR groups showed significant gains in most outcomes, with FAIL slightly favoring hypertrophy and power, though differences were modest. Strength and endurance improvements were similar between groups, and participants improved RIR estimation accuracy, particularly for bench press.
population_specificity: 42 young, resistance-trained men and women
effective_dosage: Single set of 9 exercises targeting major muscle groups, twice weekly

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if improvements in quality of life, muscle strength, and endurance from high-intensity resistance training persisted one year after completing a 16-week intervention in patients with myositis.
results_summary: The study found sustained improvements in muscle endurance at 1-year follow-up, with indications of lasting enhancements in quality of life and strength, and no increase in disease activity or damage. However, these improvements were not significantly different from the control group at follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with myositis (32 participants initially, 27 completed follow-up).
effective_dosage: High-intensity resistance training (specific dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of dynamic resistance exercises on intraocular pressure (IOP) and ocular perfusion pressure (OPP) in patients with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) and healthy controls.
results_summary: Moderate-intensity resistance training caused a progressive increase in IOP, but POAG patients showed a smaller rise compared to controls. No changes in OPP were observed, suggesting the intervention may be safe for medically treated POAG patients.
population_specificity: 26 POAG patients (age 68.9 ± 8.1 years) and 18 healthy age-matched controls (age 69.6 ± 5.9 years).
effective_dosage: One set of 10 repetitions of leg extension and biceps curl at low- (light bar) and moderate-intensity (15RM).
study_duration: Single session with measurements at baseline, after 1 and 5 minutes of recovery, and during each repetition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze how resistance training variables affect the biceps femoris long head architecture in soccer players, focusing on muscle thickness, fascicle length, and pennation angle.
results_summary: Nordic hamstring exercise (NHE) significantly improved biceps femoris long head fascicle length, especially with higher training volumes (>290 repetitions over 6-12 weeks) and a frequency of twice per week. Training frequency (once vs. twice weekly) did not show significant differences, but sufficient volume was critical for positive adaptations.
population_specificity: Soccer players
effective_dosage: >290 repetitions over 6-12 weeks, approximately 57 repetitions per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 16-week progressive resistance training (PRT) intervention could mitigate neurodegeneration and improve neuronal function in people with progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS).
results_summary: The PRT intervention significantly improved muscle strength (3-11 kg) but did not significantly affect neurodegeneration or neuronal function, though cortical gray matter volume showed a non-significant trend toward decline during baseline and intervention periods.
population_specificity: People with progressive multiple sclerosis (30 participants, 20 females, mean age 54 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity progressive resistance training combined with motivational self-talk versus resistance training alone on muscle strength and functional performance in older adults.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in 1RM and TUG test performance, but the RT-ST group demonstrated superior gains in 30 s-CS and faster TUG completion times, suggesting that self-talk enhances functional performance beyond strength gains.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 24-week bodybuilding program combining resistance training with a dietary bulk-and-cut protocol on body composition, muscle strength, and inflammatory markers in middle-aged males with obesity.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased muscle strength (deadlift +46%, squat +65%) and improved body composition (fat-free mass +3%, body fat -6%). It also reduced resting TNF-α concentrations by 15%, indicating reduced inflammation, though other inflammatory markers and lipids did not change significantly.
population_specificity: Middle-aged untrained males with obesity (BMI = 35.0 ± 4.6 kg/m², body fat = 36 ± 5%).
effective_dosage: Not specified (resistance training combined with 12-week cycles of caloric bulking and cutting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of short-term resistance training on sleep quantity and quality in young women, stratified by body fat levels.
results_summary: Six weeks of resistance training improved subjective sleep quality and reduced sleep disturbances in young women, regardless of fat mass. No significant correlations were found between sleep quality and changes in body composition.
population_specificity: Young women (n=35) categorized by body fat levels (obese vs. non-obese).
effective_dosage: Progressive six-week full-body resistance training (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether using external momentum (cheating) during resistance training affects muscle hypertrophy compared to strict form in upper extremity exercises.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in muscle thickness or circumference gains between strict form and cheat repetitions, with similar hypertrophy outcomes for both conditions. Volume load was higher for cheat repetitions, but this did not translate to superior muscle growth.
population_specificity: Thirty young adults.
effective_dosage: Four sets of 8-12 repetitions per exercise, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 10-week combined aerobic and resistance training program in improving pelvic floor muscle strength and function in postpartum women with female pelvic floor dysfunction (FPFD).
results_summary: The 10-week intervention significantly improved the maximum value of fast-twitch (type II) muscle fibers and the average value of slow-twitch (type I) muscle fibers while reducing resting tension and variability. It also enhanced rise and recovery times for both muscle fiber types.
population_specificity: Postpartum women diagnosed with female pelvic floor dysfunction (FPFD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (combined aerobic and resistance training program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training (RT), alone or combined with time-restricted eating (TRE), on body composition, mood, and sleep quality in young college adults with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: RT alone significantly decreased fat mass and increased fat-free mass, while combined with TRE, it enhanced fat loss and maintained muscle mass. RT also improved diastolic blood pressure and sleep quality, with no adverse effects on mood.
population_specificity: Young college students with overweight or obesity.
effective_dosage: Supervised resistance exercise (specific regimen not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 12-week combined interval running and resistance training (CIRRT) program on cardiac structure and performance in adolescent males with type 1 diabetes (T1D), as well as the impact of 1 month of detraining.
results_summary: The CIRRT intervention improved glycemic control (reduced HbA1c and FBG), cardiac function (increased VO2peak, ejection fraction, and fractional shortening), and cardiac structure (reduced LV internal diameter and deceleration times). Most improvements persisted after 1 month of detraining, though some reversibility was observed.
population_specificity: 48 adolescent males with T1D (aged 15.20 ± 1.78 years) and 24 healthy adolescents (aged 15.08 ± 1.67 years).
effective_dosage: Three times per week for 12 weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, followed by 1 month of detraining.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and perceived effectiveness of ballistic resistance training compared to conventional resistance training in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Both ballistic and conventional resistance training were well accepted, with no significant differences in perceived improvements in physical function or psychological well-being. No serious adverse events occurred, and muscle-related adverse event rates were similar between training groups but lower in the control group.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women (n = 109)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 12 weeks of resistance training combined with hydrolysed collagen supplementation improves patellar tendon properties in middle-aged men.
results_summary: Resistance training increased muscle strength, thickness, and tendon stiffness, with greater improvements in tendon cross-sectional area, stiffness, and Young's modulus observed in the collagen-supplemented group compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Recreationally active middle-aged men (47 ± 5 years).
effective_dosage: 30 g hydrolysed collagen + 50 mg vitamin C post-exercise, twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of resistance and aerobic training on bone quality, muscle area, and inflammatory markers in ovariectomized female mice.
results_summary: Resistance training (climbing) improved bone quality and muscle area in ovariectomized mice, similar to aerobic training, but uniquely increased anti-inflammatory IL-10 levels. Both training modalities reduced body mass compared to sedentary controls.
population_specificity: Ovariectomized (OVX) female c57bl/6 mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (protocol involved climbing for resistance training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of lower limb resistance training combined with breathing-regulation techniques on glycemic control, wound healing, and quality of life in patients with diabetes-related foot ulcers.
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in fasting blood glucose, HbA1c levels, and quality of life (physical health, psychological well-being, social relationships, and environmental aspects) over 12 weeks compared to the control group and baseline, but no significant change in wound healing was observed.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with type 2 diabetes-related foot ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel passive orthosis for neck exercises involving cervical rotation and flexion compared to traditional therapies.
results_summary: The study found significant changes in muscle effort with different stiffness configurations of the orthosis, with cervical rotations showing similar muscle activation to traditional therapies.
population_specificity: Volunteers with no clinical conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-load resistance training with blood flow restriction (LL-BFRT) reduces fall risk and improves balance function in patients with knee osteoarthritis compared to low-load resistance training alone (LL-RT).
results_summary: The study is a randomized controlled trial designed to assess the effectiveness of LL-BFRT versus LL-RT on fall risk and functional outcomes in knee osteoarthritis patients, with follow-ups at multiple time points up to 52 weeks. Results are pending as the abstract does not report findings.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare absolute and relative changes in muscle size following resistance training between males and females and assess moderating factors like muscle size measures, body region, fiber type, and training experience.
results_summary: Absolute muscle size increases slightly favored males, but relative increases were similar between sexes. Upper-body hypertrophy favored males, while lower-body results were similar; Type I fiber hypertrophy slightly favored males, but Type II results were comparable.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 18-45 years, both males and females.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of flywheel resistance training (FRT) and traditional resistance training (TRT) on deceleration and dynamic balance performance in elite badminton players.
results_summary: Flywheel resistance training (FRT) significantly improved dynamic balance (DPSI) and peak force (IMTP) compared to traditional resistance training (TRT). While no significant differences were found in deceleration deficit (DD) and change of direction (COD) tests, FRT showed greater magnitude of improvement in DD.
population_specificity: Seventeen elite male badminton players (age: 21.36 ± 2.10 years).
effective_dosage: FRT group performed training twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of resistance training (RT) on body composition, muscle strength, physical performance, and blood biomarkers in older people with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that RT significantly improved body composition (weight, BMI, PBF), muscle strength (KES), physical performance (GS, SPPB), blood biomarkers (growth hormone, FST, CK), and quality of life in older adults with sarcopenia. RT excelled in muscle strength improvements compared to WBVT.
population_specificity: Older people aged ≥65 years with sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: 3 times weekly (specific resistance training dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of aerobic-resistance training combined with royal jelly supplementation versus exercise alone on liver function, lipid profile, and oxidative stress markers in postmenopausal women with MASLD.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic-resistance training combined with royal jelly supplementation significantly improved PON1 and HDL levels while reducing oxLDL, TC, TG, LDL, ALT, and AST compared to exercise alone. The results suggest that combining exercise with royal jelly may enhance liver and metabolic health more effectively than exercise alone.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatotic Liver Disease (MASLD), average age 48.54 ± 3.88 years, BMI 27.63 ± 4.20 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 500 mg royal jelly on training days, consumed before each session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of traditional resistance training (TRT), flywheel resistance training (FWRT), and high-velocity resistance training (HVRT) on mental health and quality of life in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: TRT reduced anxiety and depression while improving social functioning; FWRT improved physical functioning, bodily pain, vitality, and emotional role; HVRT enhanced role physical, social functioning, and emotional role. TRT was most effective overall.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (n=32).
effective_dosage: Upper-limb training twice weekly with progressive intensity and volume.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether performing additional partial repetitions beyond momentary failure during resistance training enhances muscle hypertrophy compared to training only to momentary failure.
results_summary: The study found that both training to momentary failure (PLANTARMF) and training with additional partial repetitions (DORSIVF) increased medial gastrocnemius hypertrophy, but the DORSIVF condition showed a greater increase (9.6% vs. 6.7%). The results strongly supported the hypothesis that additional partial repetitions are superior for hypertrophy.
population_specificity: 23 untrained men
effective_dosage: Two weekly resistance training sessions of four sets of standing Smith machine calf raises

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of an 8-week adaptive variable-resistance training (Adaptive-VRT) intervention on chemotherapy-induced sarcopenia, fatigue, and functional restrictions in pediatric survivors of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
results_summary: The Adaptive-VRT group showed significant improvements in muscle thickness, quadriceps strength, reduced fatigue levels, and better functional performance compared to the control group adhering to standard exercise protocols.
population_specificity: Pediatric survivors of ALL aged 12-18 years who had completed maintenance chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved Adaptive-VRT but exact dosage/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of lengthened partial repetitions (LPs) versus full range of motion (ROM) resistance training on muscle hypertrophy and strength-endurance.
results_summary: Both LPs and full ROM resistance training produced similar improvements in muscle thickness and unilateral lat pulldown 10-repetition-maximum performance, with Bayesian analysis supporting the null hypothesis of equal effectiveness between the two conditions.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy, resistance-trained participants.
effective_dosage: Two training sessions per week, four exercises per session, four sets per exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of progressive resistance training programs on various outcomes in adults recovering from hip fracture.
results_summary: Progressive resistance training improved functional capacity, strength, balance, walking speed, flexibility, and cardiorespiratory fitness in post-hip fracture patients, but effects on independence, quality of life, self-reported physical disability, depression, and cognitive ability were inconclusive.
population_specificity: Adults over 65 years (mean age 77.80) recovering from hip fracture, typically 3-12 months post-fracture.
effective_dosage: Intensity progressed from 60% to 80% of 1RM, with 3-4 lower limb exercises (hip and knee movements).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare perceptual responses (discomfort, exertion, and general feelings) between resistance training to momentary muscular failure (FAIL) and training with perceived repetitions in reserve (RIR).
results_summary: The study found that training to FAIL resulted in slightly greater perceived discomfort (RPD) and exertion (RPE) compared to RIR, while RIR led to more positive general feelings (FS). Bayesian analysis showed high probability (pd = 100%) for these differences.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained males (n = 12) and females (n = 6).
effective_dosage: Two resistance training sessions per week, with leg press and leg extension exercises performed either to FAIL or perceived 2-RIR and 1-RIR, respectively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training on hemodynamic outcomes (blood pressure, heart rate, and VO2max) in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, lowered resting heart rate, and improved VO2max, with greater benefits observed in interventions lasting over 12 weeks. High heterogeneity in blood pressure outcomes and limited subgroup data restrict generalizability.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes.
study_duration: Varied, with greater reductions in interventions lasting over 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the preventive effects of varying intensity progressive resistance exercise on breast cancer-related lymphedema in patients who underwent axillary lymph node dissection.
results_summary: Resistance exercise improved muscle strength and reduced lymphedema markers, with moderate-high-intensity exercise showing greater effectiveness than low intensity. Adverse events were minimal, indicating good safety.
population_specificity: 114 breast cancer patients who underwent axillary lymph node dissection.
effective_dosage: Low-intensity progressive resistance exercise (group 1) and moderate-high-intensity progressive resistance exercise (group 2).
study_duration: Intervention and follow-up assessments at post-intervention, 3 months, and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week resistance training program could improve cognitive performance and slow neuronal loss in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found that resistance training improved response time on the Go/No-go task and increased cortical thickness in the right parahippocampal gyrus, particularly in individuals at high MCI risk. These changes were associated with cognitive improvements, suggesting neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-85 years, including 38 females and 32 males, stratified by MCI risk (high or low based on MoCA scores).
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week lower limb resistance training program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the attitudes and preferences of people with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) toward blood flow restricted resistance training (BFR-RT) and assess its acceptability and impact on muscle strength, functional capacity, quality of life, and pain.
results_summary: The study found that BFR-RT was highly acceptable (100% approval), had good adherence (81%), and significantly improved strength, functional performance, and pain in people with RA, though no improvements in quality of life were observed.
population_specificity: People with rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
effective_dosage: No more than three sessions per week, commencing at low-to-moderate intensity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining BOSU ball exercises with conventional resistance training in improving joint stability and function after ACL reconstruction in adolescent athletes.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly better knee joint stability, balance, strength ratios, and functional outcomes compared to the control group at 6 and 12 months post-surgery. The combination of BOSU ball training and resistance exercises was more effective than traditional rehabilitation alone.
population_specificity: Adolescent athletes (ages 14-18) who underwent ACL reconstruction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training, alone or combined with time-restricted eating, on skeletal muscle tissue quantity, quality, function, and cardiometabolic health in postmenopausal women with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: The study will compare resistance training combined with time-restricted eating or caloric restriction to assess changes in skeletal muscle tissue, intermuscular adipose tissue, strength, power, and cardiometabolic risk factors, with results pending follow-up.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 50-65 with a BMI of 25-40 kg/m², sedentary lifestyle, and no severe metabolic impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroplastic effects of 4-week expiratory muscle strength training (EMST) in healthy young adults, focusing on molecular and functional changes.
results_summary: The study found significant increases in maximum expiratory pressure (MEP) and serum BDNF levels post-training, along with functional activation changes in eight brain regions, but no significant changes in IGF-1 levels or white matter microstructure.
population_specificity: Five healthy young adult men aged 19-35 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low load-blood flow restriction training (LL-BFRt), sham LL-BFRt, and high load-resistance training (HL-Rt) on quadriceps strength, dynamic stability, and functional performance.
results_summary: Both LL-BFRt and HL-Rt significantly improved quadriceps strength, dynamic stability (SEBT), and functional performance (SLHT) over 8 weeks, with no significant improvements in the sham LL-BFRt group. The improvements in LL-BFRt and HL-Rt were comparable, suggesting both methods are effective.
population_specificity: 63 basketball and rugby players in Bali, Indonesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and feasibility of a 12-week resistance training program in post-cardiac surgery patients, with a focus on sex-specific effects.
results_summary: The study found the resistance training program safe and feasible, with no serious adverse events and high session completion rates. Participants showed positive trends in strength, endurance, and functional capacity, with females experiencing greater relative improvements than males.
population_specificity: Adult patients post open-heart surgery who had completed traditional cardiac rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: 12-week strength training exercise intervention (mean 34.8/36 sessions completed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the comparative effectiveness of protein supplementation, resistance training, and their combination on body composition and physical function in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The study found that combining resistance training with protein supplementation significantly improved lean body mass, muscle mass, strength, and physical function in older adults compared to protein supplementation alone. Resistance training alone also showed significant improvements in muscle strength and physical function.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 50 years and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess rehabilitation providers' perceptions and needs for adopting i-STRONGER, a high-intensity resistance training approach, in skilled nursing facilities (SNFs).
results_summary: i-STRONGER was endorsed as feasible and adaptable, with initial hesitancies about patient abilities and motivation. Providers observed improvements in patient function and motivation, leading to greater acceptance of the program.
population_specificity: Older adults in skilled nursing facilities (SNFs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of increasing weekly sets of resistance training versus maintaining a constant set volume on muscular adaptations over 12 weeks.
results_summary: The study found that increasing weekly sets (4SG and 2SG groups) led to greater improvements in 1RM and vastus lateralis cross-sectional area compared to the constant volume group (CG), but no additional benefits were observed for total muscle thickness (∑MT).
population_specificity: Thirty females with an average resistance training experience of 2.1 ± 1.0 years.
effective_dosage: 22 sets per week (CG), progressive increases in sets (2SG and 4SG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of 8-week tDCS combined with resistance training on pull-up performance in male college students.
results_summary: Both resistance training alone and combined with tDCS significantly improved pull-up endurance and lat pull-down peak force, with no significant difference between groups. The RT + tDCS group showed reduced tricep brachii coactivation, suggesting improved elbow flexion efficiency.
population_specificity: Male college students
effective_dosage: Lat pull-down training programs (specific dosage not detailed); tDCS was administered for 20 minutes before each RT session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training on the main dimensions of executive function in cognitively healthy older adults compared to active or passive control groups.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a systematic review and meta-analysis to evaluate resistance training's impact on executive function, but results are not yet available as this is a proposed review.
population_specificity: Cognitively healthy older adults aged ≥60 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week body-weight-based resistance training program improves balance ability and reduces fear of falling in community-dwelling older women.
results_summary: The study found that the resistance training program significantly improved lower-extremity muscle strength and balance ability but did not reduce fear of falling. Significant improvements were observed in chair stand test scores and one-leg standing times, but no change was noted in fear of falling scores.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older women (n=23, aged not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a 10-week free weight resistance training program on cognitive function in healthy young adults.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training led to significant changes in cognitive processing, particularly in early processing measures (FPRTs), with the experimental group showing improved attention allocation to complex structures and enhanced efficiency for simpler texts. Increased strength was associated with these cognitive improvements.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of RPE-based resistance training (using RIR) versus %1RM-based resistance training for strength gains in cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: Both RPE and %1RM methods resulted in significant strength gains across all exercises, with no statistically significant differences between groups and trivial effect sizes favoring either method. RPE-based training was found to be similarly effective to %1RM-based training.
population_specificity: Sixteen male patients (age 60 ± 8) with a history of coronary artery disease.
effective_dosage: Three resistance training sessions per week, with the same exercise selection, sets, repetitions, and rest periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of combined resistance and aerobic training in alleviating depressive symptoms among individuals with depression.
results_summary: The study found that resistance combined with aerobic training significantly improved depressive symptoms, particularly in middle-aged and elderly patients and those with moderate depression. Optimal results were seen with moderate duration (9-24 weeks), frequency (3-4 times per week), total weekly duration (>180 min), and supervised training.
population_specificity: Individuals with depression, particularly middle-aged and elderly patients and those with moderate depression.
effective_dosage: 3-4 times per week, total weekly duration >180 min

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the neural mechanisms, specifically motor unit adaptations, responsible for strength gains in untrained muscles following unilateral resistance training (cross-education).
results_summary: The study found significant increases in maximal voluntary force (MVF) in both trained (+19%) and untrained (+10%) muscles after 8 weeks of resistance training, accompanied by decreased motor unit recruitment thresholds and higher net discharge rates, indicating enhanced spinal motoneuron output.
population_specificity: Nine participants performing unilateral resistance training and nine control individuals (total n=18).
effective_dosage: Not specified (unilateral resistance training protocol details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dual-task resistance training versus traditional resistance training on strength, pain, range of motion, and functionality in patients rehabilitating from elbow fractures.
results_summary: Dual-task resistance training improved strength and reduced pain more than traditional resistance training, and only the dual-task group showed improvements in kinesiophobia. Both groups enhanced strength, reduced pain, improved functionality, and increased range of motion after 12 weeks.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing rehabilitation for elbow fractures (N=32).
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week program, frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-duration, high-intensity stretching combined with resistance training (RT) produces complementary or redundant muscular adaptations in well-trained individuals.
results_summary: The study found that combining stretching and RT led to increased range of motion (25.9%), strength (11.4%), and muscle thickness (7.4%-23.4%), with meaningful changes in muscle architecture at multiple sites. However, generalizability is limited due to the case-study design.
population_specificity: Competitive bodybuilder
effective_dosage: 60 minutes of stretching 6x/week alongside habitual RT

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 1 year of supervised resistance training at two different intensities (heavy and moderate) positively influenced bone health in older adults.
results_summary: Heavy resistance training (HRT) increased short-term bone formation (PINP rise) after the first year, but this effect was not maintained long-term. Bone mineral density (BMD) decreased across all groups over 4 years, and resistance training did not significantly alter BMD or long-term bone degradation markers.
population_specificity: Older adults at retirement age (mean age: 66 ± 3 years, n = 451, 58% women).
effective_dosage: Heavy resistance training (HRT) and moderate intensity training (MIT); exact dosage not specified.
study_duration: 1 year of supervised training, with follow-ups at years 2 and 4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether eccentric resistance training (ERT) improves body function, activities of daily living (ADL), cognition, strength, gait, quality of life, and self-perceived health after stroke.
results_summary: ERT showed significantly better results in improving body function, gait, and strength in stroke patients, with low-moderate quality evidence supporting its effectiveness. No harm was documented, and the intervention was well-accepted.
population_specificity: Stroke patients of both sexes, aged 18 or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of recruitment, adherence, and compliance with heavy slow resistance training in patients with lateral epicondylalgia, as well as describe within-group changes in secondary outcomes.
results_summary: Only 32% of participants complied with heavy slow resistance training, mainly due to pain aggravation. Patient-reported and performance-based outcomes improved in all groups, but compliance issues suggest resistance training may not be suitable for tennis elbow patients.
population_specificity: Patients with lateral epicondylalgia (tennis elbow) recruited from an outpatient clinic.
study_duration: Follow-up at 3 and 6 months (intervention duration not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of 8 weeks of resistance training on body mass and body composition in post-COVID-19 elderly adults and to compare the agreement between BIA and DXA methods for measuring body composition.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in body mass or body composition after 8 weeks of resistance training. BIA overestimated baseline body mass and fat-free mass while underestimating fat mass compared to DXA, but both methods showed no significant differences in tracking intervention-induced changes.
population_specificity: Post-COVID-19 elderly adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of resistance training on joint flexibility in healthy adults through a systematic review, meta-analysis, and meta-regression.
results_summary: The pooled effect size for resistance training on flexibility was moderate (g = 0.6325), with high-intensity protocols showing a magnified effect. However, the high overall risk of bias and substantial heterogeneity limit definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged ≥18 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (resistance training protocols varied in intensity).

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of resistance training on cardiometabolic health-related outcomes in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and overweight/obesity.
results_summary: Resistance training improved waist circumference, waist-to-hip ratio, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, triglycerides, fasting blood glucose, fasting insulin, and glycated hemoglobin compared with standard treatment. The risk of bias was low to unclear, and the quality of evidence was very low to moderate.
population_specificity: Adults diagnosed with T2DM and concurrent overweight/obesity (BMI ≥25 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different combinations of aerobic and resistance training on college students' health self-efficacy, body image, and subjective well-being during COVID-19.
results_summary: All three exercise programs improved health self-efficacy, with the AE+RE group showing significantly better body image and subjective well-being compared to the other groups. Female students scored higher than males on all measured outcomes.
population_specificity: College students (41 participants, convenience sampling)
effective_dosage: 3 days per week, 30 min per session (AE+RE, RE+AE); 5 days per week (control)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different isometric resistance training (IRT) protocols on blood pressure improvement in overweight or obese college students.
results_summary: Long-term IRT intervention significantly reduced systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP), and mean arterial pressure (MAP) in multiple groups, while acute exercise temporarily increased cardiovascular responses without excessive pressure.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese college students with irregular exercise habits.
effective_dosage: Exercise intervention three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a school-based resistance training program, with and without gamification, on muscular fitness, body composition, motivation, and enjoyment in children.
results_summary: The study protocol describes an 8-week intervention comparing resistance training with gamification, resistance training alone, and a control group, but results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children in grades 5 and 6 (10-12 years old) from 6 schools in Valencia, Spain.
effective_dosage: 15 minutes of RT Functional HIIT circuit program (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of resistance training on cognition and brain anatomy in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Resistance training improved verbal episodic memory, preserved gray matter volume in the right hippocampus and precuneus, enhanced white matter integrity, and showed protective effects against atrophy in specific brain regions compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of resistance training on inflammatory biomarkers, body composition, and functional capacity in healthy adults aged 60 years and over, and to examine the moderating effect of exercise variables on inflammatory markers.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly reduced CRP levels and improved leg extension strength and 6-MWT performance, but did not significantly affect TNF-α or IL-6 levels.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 60 years and over.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training (RT) alone and combined with nandrolone decanoate (ND) on inflammatory, apoptotic, oxidative stress responses, and adiponectin expression in cardiac tissue.
results_summary: RT significantly increased NFκβ, GPX, and adiponectin levels. ND administration further elevated NFκβ and TNF-α, with RTA showing higher TNF-α and adiponectin responses compared to other groups. A strong correlation was found between training volume and GPX expression.
population_specificity: Male C57Bl/6J mice, 3 months old.
effective_dosage: 38 mg·kg⁻¹ ND injected once per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the duration of type 2 diabetes (T2DM) impacts the efficacy of a 16-week elastic band resistance training and diabetes education intervention on physical functioning, glycemia, and frailty in older adults.
