results_summary: Both short- and long-duration T2DM groups improved in physical functioning and frailty status, while the long-duration group showed significantly greater improvements in A1C compared to the short-duration group.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥65 years) with T2DM and pre-frailty/frailty.
effective_dosage: Not specified (elastic band resistance training and diabetes education).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of resistance training on cardiovascular risk factors in adults with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Resistance training significantly improved multiple cardiovascular risk factors, including reductions in hemoglobin A1C, fasting blood sugar, insulin, HOMA-IR, triglycerides, body weight, fat percentage, and waist circumference, while increasing high-density lipoprotein.
population_specificity: Adults with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of resistance training on pain, strength, and function in osteoarthritis (OA) patients, with subgroup analyses by intervention duration and affected joint (knee or hip).
results_summary: Resistance training significantly improved pain, strength, and function in OA patients, with benefits observed across different intervention durations (though function improvements required at least 5 weeks) and in both knee and hip OA.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (knee or hip).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the variation in resistance training response among breast cancer patients undergoing treatment, focusing on changes in volume-load and progression trajectories.
results_summary: The study found a positive linear and negative quadratic component in volume-load changes, indicating non-linear progression that eventually plateaus. Variation between individuals and exercises was substantial, with individual variation being approximately four times larger than between-exercise variation.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients undergoing tumor therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of resistance training on the skeletal muscle proteome and neuromuscular function in older versus younger women.
results_summary: Resistance training increased mitochondrial biogenesis proteins in older women but did not normalize age-related declines in skeletal muscle contraction proteins. Older women showed poorer leg strength and neuromuscular function despite training, but some proteins were associated with greater handgrip strength.
population_specificity: Seven young (22 ± 6 years) and eight older (63 ± 5 years) women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of traditional set (TS), paired-set (PS), and super-set (SS) resistance training methods on muscle fatigue (strength and training volume) in the hamstrings and quadriceps.
results_summary: PS and SS reduced hamstring strength, while all methods reduced quadriceps strength. PS showed higher total training volume than TS and SS, while SS had better time efficiency.
population_specificity: Thirteen healthy, untrained men.
effective_dosage: Three sets of leg curl and leg extension exercises with 60 s rest intervals (varied by method).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different types of resistance training (isometric, isokinetic, and isotonic) on pain, function, and quadriceps strength in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that all three types of resistance training improved pain and knee-joint function in KOA patients, with isokinetic muscle strengthening (IKMS) showing the best results in pain relief, functional improvement, and knee extension torque compared to conventional physiotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of functional resistance training (FRT) during walking when resistance was applied to the knee alone versus both the hip and knee joints.
results_summary: Adding resistance to the hip increased hip flexion moment and concentric power during swing phase but did not significantly differ from knee-only resistance in muscle activation, aftereffects, peripheral fatigue, or corticospinal excitability. Both configurations produced similar changes in these variables.
population_specificity: Fourteen non-disabled individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether guided resistance training, with or without oral semaglutide, improves adherence and persistence of the SLIMM intervention in reducing sedentary behavior among persons with CKD.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so definitive results are not yet available. However, the design suggests potential benefits of guided resistance training in enhancing physical activity adherence and reducing sedentary duration in CKD patients.
population_specificity: Persons with chronic kidney disease (eGFR 20 to ≤60 ml/min/1.73 m²).
effective_dosage: Not specified (guided resistance training sessions per month and daily independent exercises prescribed).
study_duration: 3-month sedentary activity coaching followed by a 9-month randomized controlled trial (total 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an 8-week flywheel resistance training program on countermovement jump performance and resting stiffness of the vastus lateralis muscle in physically active adults.
results_summary: The training group showed significant improvements in jump height, rate of force development, peak power, and peak force, while the control group did not. No significant changes were observed in resting muscle stiffness for either group.
population_specificity: Physically active adults
effective_dosage: Individually allocated high-load flywheel inertia (specific amount not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the local, proximal, and distal effects of resistance training with blood flow restriction (BFR) on the strength and size of upper limb muscles in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training with BFR, whether using high or low loads, generally resulted in greater gains in muscle strength and size compared to resistance training without BFR. However, caution is advised due to high heterogeneity in study methods.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals

study_goal: To summarize and analyze evidence on the effects of resistance training on pain, functionality, and quality of life in women with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: Resistance training reduced pain and improved functionality and quality of life in women with fibromyalgia, with most studies showing positive outcomes despite varying risks of bias. The intervention was deemed effective and safe when performed twice weekly with progressive loads.
population_specificity: Female patients with fibromyalgia, regardless of age.
effective_dosage: Progressive loads ranging from 40 to 80% of one-repetition maximum, performed twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile evidence on the impact of resistance training on hepatic and clinical parameters in individuals diagnosed with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: Resistance training significantly reduced liver fat, liver enzymes, and insulin resistance in adults with MASLD, with high adherence rates (>90%) compared to aerobic training.
population_specificity: 232 adult participants diagnosed with MASLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and effects of a proximal muscle resistance training program on walking and muscle performance in people with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking distance (6-Minute Walk Test), walking speed (Timed 25-Foot Walk Test), and muscle performance, with high participant satisfaction and no serious adverse events. No changes were observed in daily step count or trunk/pelvis kinematics.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (Expanded Disability Status Scale Score <6.0, median score 3.5).
effective_dosage: Resistance training targeting hip abduction and trunk muscles (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of resistance training on cancer-related fatigue (CRF) and quality of life (QoL) in people with cancer, comparing it to no training across different periods of treatment and assessment.
results_summary: Resistance training during anticancer therapy probably has a beneficial effect on short-term CRF and may improve short-term QoL, though evidence for medium- and long-term effects is uncertain. Resistance training after therapy may have a small beneficial effect on short-term QoL, but data on long-term outcomes are sparse.
population_specificity: Adults with various types of cancer, receiving resistance training during or after anticancer therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (structured, at least five sessions with face-to-face instruction).
study_duration: Varied by study (short-term up to 12 weeks, medium-term 12 weeks to 6 months, long-term 6 months or longer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of machine-based resistance training on strength and functional capacity in older adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis revealed significant improvements in functional outcomes (standardized mean change = 0.72) and strength outcomes (standardized mean change = 0.71) for machine-based resistance training compared to control conditions. Substantial heterogeneity was noted in the manipulation of training variables and effect sizes across studies.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (>60 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training on knee extensor muscle hypertrophy in adults aged 65 and older.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly increased muscle size and fiber area but did not significantly affect leg lean mass. Training duration influenced type II fiber area response, while weekly sets and age did not significantly impact outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65 years and older.
study_duration: Varied across studies (meta-analysis included multiple durations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 12 weeks of resistance training on oxidative status, muscle strength, functional capacity, quality of life, and fatigue in women with Multiple Sclerosis.
results_summary: Resistance training improved muscle strength, functional capacity, and quality of life while reducing fatigue in women with MS, but did not significantly affect oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-45 with relapsing-remitting MS (EDSS ≤ 4) and a control group of healthy age-matched women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of resistance training in preventing sarcopenia among breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly reduced body fat, increased lean body mass, and improved muscle strength and physical performance in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. The effects were consistent across multiple measures, including handgrip strength, leg press strength, and overall physical performance.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 20-to-90-min sessions 2-4 times weekly, 8-12 repetitions at 40%-90% of one-repetition maximum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the ergogenic effects of intra-session supplementation of highly branched cyclic dextrin (HBCD) on mechanical, metabolic, and perceptual responses during resistance training.
results_summary: HBCD supplementation was well-tolerated, improved repetition velocity in men but not women, tended to increase lactate values, and did not significantly affect fatigue perception.
population_specificity: 30 physically active individuals (15 men and 15 women)
effective_dosage: 45 g of HBCD diluted in 750 mL of beverage, consumed in 50 mL doses before each set

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between protein intake and sarcopenia risk in Korean older adults, with a focus on the potential role of resistance training in managing sarcopenia.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that lower protein intake (<0.8 g/kg/day) was significantly associated with a higher risk of sarcopenia and low handgrip strength (HGS) compared to higher intake levels (0.8-1.2 g/kg/day and ≥1.2 g/kg/day). The study highlighted the need for further RCTs combining protein supplementation and resistance training to establish optimal protein intake recommendations.
population_specificity: Korean adults aged 65 and older.
effective_dosage: Protein intake levels: <0.8 g/kg/day, 0.8-1.2 g/kg/day, and ≥1.2 g/kg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Urolithin A (UA) supplementation on muscle endurance, strength, inflammation, oxidative stress, and protein metabolism in resistance-trained male athletes.
results_summary: After 8 weeks of UA supplementation, the study found non-significant improvements in 1RM bench press and squat, along with reduced oxidative stress and inflammation levels.
population_specificity: Resistance-trained male athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how variables like age and training duration affect the efficacy of creatine supplementation combined with resistance training for improving muscle strength.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation combined with resistance training significantly increased upper-body strength compared to a placebo, with a weighted mean difference of 4.43 kg. The study included 23 studies but did not fully detail the impact of confounding variables.
population_specificity: Primarily males (447 participants), with some females (49 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training combined with creatine-hydrochloride (Cr-HCl) or creatine monohydrate (CrM) supplementation on anabolic/catabolic hormones, strength, and body composition.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training with creatine supplementation significantly increased strength, muscle mass, and anabolic hormones (GH, IGF-1, testosterone/cortisol ratio) while decreasing body fat and catabolic hormones (cortisol, ACTH). Cr-HCl showed no additional benefits over CrM.
population_specificity: 40 participants aged 18-25 years.
effective_dosage: Cr-HCl (0.03 g/kg body mass), CrM-loading phase (0.3 g/kg for 5 days, then 0.03 g/kg for 51 days), CrM-without loading phase (0.03 g/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of physical activity and nutritional interventions, including assisted resistance training, on sarcopenia in patients with advanced colorectal cancer.
results_summary: Assisted resistance training and protein supplementation showed improvement in muscle mass in some studies, but evidence was limited due to small sample sizes and moderate-to-high risk of bias. Recruitment to physical activity interventions was low, though adherence to supervised interventions was high.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced colorectal cancer (587 participants out of 1461 total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of whey protein supplementation combined with resistance training on glycemic control, muscle strength, quality of life, and body composition in older adults with Type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both the whey protein and placebo groups showed improvements in muscle strength and mass, with no significant additional benefit from whey protein. Whey protein slightly increased blood urea but remained within normal limits and showed a small improvement in mental health without clinical significance.
population_specificity: Older adults with non-insulin-dependent Type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 33 g of whey protein twice a week on resistance training days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of resistance training (RT) and a high-protein diet (HPD) on body composition, muscle thickness, and strength capacity in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: RT significantly increased skeletal muscle mass, reduced fat mass in one group, and improved muscle thickness and strength (grip strength, squat, and deadlift). HPD alone had minimal effects on strength but no impact on body composition.
population_specificity: Healthy postmenopausal women (age 58.2 ± 5.6 years).
effective_dosage: RT: 3 sessions/week, 5 exercises each; HPD: 2.5 g/kg fat-free mass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the added effect of creatine supplementation on changes in body composition (lean body mass, body fat percentage, and body fat mass) with resistance training in adults younger than 50 years.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation increased lean body mass by 1.14 kg and reduced body fat percentage by 0.88% and body fat mass by 0.73 kg compared to resistance training alone. No differences were found based on training status or carbohydrate co-ingestion, and training volume did not moderate the effects.
population_specificity: Adults younger than 50 years
effective_dosage: 7 g or 0.3 g/kg of body mass per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of creatine supplementation protocol parameters (dose and form) on body mass and estimates of fat-free and fat mass, particularly when combined with resistance training.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation had a small but statistically significant effect on body mass, fat-free mass, and body fat percentage, with more robust results when combined with resistance training. The analysis included 143 randomized controlled trials, showing consistent but modest improvements.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract (general population engaging in resistance training implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of nutritional supplementation (carbohydrates, protein, and/or amino acids) on recovery, muscle growth, and strength expression in resistance training.
results_summary: The study found that nutritional supplementation strategies involving carbohydrates, protein, and/or amino acids enhance muscular responses, including hypertrophy and strength, by influencing nutrient-cell signaling and timing around resistance exercise.
population_specificity: Strength and power athletes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ashwagandha supplementation combined with resistance training improves muscle strength, size, and cardio-respiratory endurance in healthy adults.
results_summary: Ashwagandha supplementation significantly improved muscle strength (bench press, leg press), muscle size (arm, chest, thigh girth), and endurance compared to placebo, with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Healthy male and female participants aged 18-45 years who engaged in regular physical activity.
effective_dosage: 300 mg capsules twice daily (600 mg total daily dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Panax ginseng supplementation reduces resistance to exercise-induced muscle damage (EIMD) following resistance training.
results_summary: The study found conflicting evidence regarding Panax ginseng's effects on markers of muscle damage, function, and soreness. The main conclusion was that Panax ginseng does not attenuate EIMD markers, though research remains preliminary.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether blood-flow restricted resistance training (BFR-T) could prevent or slow skeletal muscle mass loss and improve functional capacity and mental health in patients with pancreatic, biliary tract, and liver cancer.
results_summary: The study is ongoing (PREV-Ex trial), but the abstract outlines the planned evaluation of BFR-T's effects on muscle thickness, cross-sectional area, biomarkers, patient-reported outcomes, physical fitness, and clinical outcomes. Expected benefits include improved prognosis and independence for patients.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with pancreatic, biliary tract, and liver cancer.
effective_dosage: Low-load BFR-T (specific load not detailed) with protein supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of omega-3 fatty acids supplementation combined with resistance training on muscle strength and mass.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed that omega-3 fatty acids supplementation and resistance training significantly improved muscle strength but had no significant effect on muscle mass. The findings suggest potential benefits for combating muscular dysfunction.
population_specificity: Elderly people (implied by the conclusion regarding quality of life).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of an eight-week combined resistance-endurance training program, with or without omega-3 supplementation, on ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 levels in elderly women.
results_summary: Resistance training combined with endurance training significantly reduced ICAM-1 and VCAM-1 levels, with additional benefits observed when paired with omega-3 supplementation. The intervention also significantly decreased insulin resistance and body fat percentage.
population_specificity: Elderly women (average age 66.7 ± 4.13 years)
effective_dosage: Resistance training at 70% of 1RM, 10 repetitions per exercise for two sets, three sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanisms, efficacy, and side effects of various anti-aging measures, including resistance training, on aging gonadal function.
results_summary: The abstract mentions resistance training as one of the anti-aging measures but does not provide specific results regarding its effects on gonadal function. More clinical trials are suggested to solidify the foundation of this topic.
population_specificity: Aging individuals with hypogonadism (men with LOH and ED, women with POI and menopause).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current literature on the effects of resistance training (RT) and nutrition interventions for improving muscle strength, physical function, and muscle mass in renal cachexia patients.
results_summary: RT was found to improve muscle strength and, in some cases, physical function, though effects on muscle mass were mixed. Combined RT and aerobic training (AT) showed benefits for overall functional capacity, with no superior protocol identified (inter/intra-dialysis vs. home-based).
population_specificity: Patients with renal cachexia (characterized by weight loss, muscle wasting, and reduced physical function).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of whey protein supplementation with or without resistance training on muscle mass, strength, and physical performance in older patients with sarcopenia.
results_summary: Whey protein significantly improved muscle mass, gait speed, and handgrip strength when combined with resistance training. It also reduced interleukin-6, increased insulin-like growth factor-1 and albumin, and enhanced energy and protein intake without affecting BMI, weight, or fat mass.
population_specificity: Older patients (community or hospital-based) diagnosed with sarcopenia according to EWGSOP or AWGS criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 6 weeks of resistance training combined with aerobic training and Tirzepatide supplementation on lipid profiles, insulin resistance, anthropometrics, and physical fitness in prediabetic obese soldiers.
results_summary: Combined resistance and aerobic training (RT+AT) alone was more effective than Tirzepatide supplementation for improving cardiorespiratory fitness, strength, and insulin modulation. Tirzepatide combined with exercise did not show significant advantages over exercise alone, and different doses of Tirzepatide (2.5 mg vs. 5 mg) did not differ significantly in outcomes.
population_specificity: Prediabetic obese male soldiers
effective_dosage: Tirzepatide 2.5 mg and 5 mg (frequency not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of non-pharmacological interventions, including resistance training, for sarcopenia prevention in menopausal women aged 40-60.
results_summary: Resistance training had a small effect on lean body mass, with longer duration (>12 weeks) and higher frequency (60-90 min, 3 sessions/week) showing small to moderate effects. Exercise improved muscle mass and strength, particularly handgrip and knee extension strength.
population_specificity: Menopausal women aged 40-60.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of omega-3 PUFA supplementation on upper-extremity muscle strength and lower-extremity physical function in individuals with sarcopenia or at high risk for sarcopenia.
results_summary: High-dose omega-3 PUFA supplementation (more than 2.5 g/day) showed the greatest improvement in upper-extremity muscle strength and lower-extremity physical function compared to placebo/standard care, but did not significantly increase skeletal muscle mass, fat mass, or overall body weight.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with sarcopenia or at high risk for sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: More than 2.5 g/day of omega-3 PUFAs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the combined effects of resistance training and creatine supplementation on regional muscle hypertrophy using direct imaging measures.
results_summary: The study found a very small but statistically significant increase in muscle hypertrophy when creatine supplementation was combined with resistance training compared to resistance training alone, with slightly greater benefits in younger adults. The effects were consistent across upper and lower body measurements.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a combined exercise (back extensor strengthening) and nutrition (protein supplementation) intervention for treating spinal sarcopenia in older women.
results_summary: The intervention did not significantly improve muscle mass or strength but showed modest improvements in physical performance (short physical performance battery) and back performance scale scores.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older women (mean age 72.5 ± 4.0 years) diagnosed with spinal sarcopenia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (protein supplementation details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of 2 years of creatine monohydrate supplementation combined with resistance training and walking on bone health in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation had no effect on bone mineral density (BMD) at the femoral neck, total hip, or lumbar spine but improved some bone geometric properties at the proximal femur. It also reduced walking time over 80 meters and increased lean tissue mass in a subanalysis, but had no effect on muscular strength.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (mean age 59 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of resistance training combined with creatine monohydrate supplementation on oxidative stress, antioxidant defense, muscle strength, and quality of life in older adults.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA and 8-OHDG) and increased antioxidant levels (GPX and TAC). It also improved muscle strength and quality of life, with creatine supplementation potentially doubling strength gains.
population_specificity: Non-athlete older adults (mean age 68.1 ± 7.2 years), including men and women.
effective_dosage: 0.1 g/kg of body weight daily (creatine monohydrate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether protein supplementation enhances body composition outcomes (lean body mass and fat mass) in older adults undergoing resistance training.
results_summary: Protein supplementation may benefit older adults with prior training experience, insufficient protein intake, or frailty symptoms, but it does not significantly improve outcomes in untrained, healthy individuals. Factors like age and supplementation protocol characteristics influence effectiveness.
population_specificity: Older adults (specific age range not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of exercise (including resistance training) with and without protein supplementation on muscle strength and function in older adults with sarcopenic obesity.
results_summary: The meta-review found that exercise, with or without protein supplementation, improved body composition (reduced body fat percentage) and functional outcomes (gait speed and grip strength) in older adults with sarcopenic obesity. However, the literature remains limited, and further investigation is needed to determine the combined effects of exercise and protein supplementation.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥65 years with sarcopenic obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential mechanisms by which creatine supplementation could affect endurance performance and highlight nuances in the literature.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation enhances anaerobic work capacity, increases time to exhaustion during high-intensity endurance activities, and may improve performance in sports requiring repeated surges or end spurts. However, mixed results were observed for time trial performances, and increased body mass may offset benefits in weight-bearing activities.
population_specificity: Not specified (general endurance athletes and sports requiring intermittent high-intensity efforts).
interactions: Co-ingestion with carbohydrates enhances glycogen resynthesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of chia flour, whey protein, and a placebo alongside resistance training on fat-free mass and strength gains in untrained young men.
results_summary: Resistance training increased fat-free mass and strength similarly across all groups, with no significant additional benefit from whey protein or chia flour over the placebo. FFM increased by 2.3% in the whey protein group.
population_specificity: Untrained young men
effective_dosage: 30 g whey protein concentrate (23 g protein) or 50 g chia flour (20 g protein) post-training, three times per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impacts of protein supplementation and resistance training on sarcopenic obesity in older adults.
results_summary: The combination of resistance training and whey protein supplementation improved sarcopenic conditions and weight status, with benefits in lean muscle mass and biomarkers. However, there was a lack of consistency in exercise design among interventions.
population_specificity: Older adults with sarcopenic obesity.
effective_dosage: Protein intake ranged from 1.0 to 1.8 g/kg/BW/day; exercise was performed 2-3 times per week for 1 hour per session.
study_duration: Not specified (duration of exercise sessions was 1 hour, but total study duration was not clearly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 32-week resistance training intervention with elastic bands, with or without microfiltered seawater supplementation, on isokinetic strength, bone mineral density, body composition, and subjective quality of life in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study explored the impact of resistance training on postmenopausal women, measuring outcomes like strength, bone density, body composition, and quality of life, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Untrained postmenopausal women (age: 70.00 ± 6.26 years; BMI: 22.05 ± 3.20 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of creatine versus placebo supplementation on muscle strength, thickness, endurance, and body composition using blood flow restriction versus traditional resistance training.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study compared creatine and placebo effects across different training paradigms.
population_specificity: Seventeen healthy males.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of resistance training, alone or combined with protein, for treating sarcopenic obesity in retirement-age individuals.
results_summary: Resistance training significantly reduced body fat (-1.53%), increased muscle mass (2.72%) and strength (4.42 kg), and slightly improved gait speed (0.17 m/s). Combining protein with exercise further reduced fat mass (-0.80 kg).
population_specificity: Community-dwelling individuals with sarcopenic obesity, mean age 50-70 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current evidence for creatine supplementation in advanced chronic liver disease, particularly in sarcopenic cirrhotic patients, and its potential benefits on complications like encephalopathy and fatigue.
results_summary: The abstract suggests creatine supplementation may have beneficial effects on sarcopenia, fatty liver, encephalopathy, and fatigue in advanced chronic liver disease, though human studies are lacking and evidence is primarily from animal models. Further research is needed to confirm these potential benefits.
population_specificity: Sarcopenic cirrhotic patients and animal models of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3PUFA) supplementation affects muscle mass, strength, and function in healthy young and older adults, including its interaction with resistance training.
results_summary: n-3PUFA supplementation showed a very small but significant positive effect on muscle strength but had no significant impact on muscle mass or function. Subgroup analyses indicated that age, dosage, or co-supplementation with resistance training did not influence these outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy young and older adults (total 1443 participants: 913 females, 520 males).
effective_dosage: Subgroup analyses included dosages <2 g/day and ≥2 g/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review body composition data of competitive bodybuilding athletes to provide recommended values for preparation and during competition.
results_summary: The review found significant reductions in body fat (30-60%) during competition preparation while lean mass was mostly maintained, with resistance training volume remaining high and aerobic training increasing. Energy intake and macronutrient distribution findings were unclear and require further study.
population_specificity: Competitive bodybuilding athletes (male and female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different combinations of resistance training-based interventions on the musculoskeletal health of older male adults with sarcopenia.
results_summary: Resistance training combined with aerobic training or nutritional supplements (protein and vitamins) showed beneficial effects on strength, functionality, and body composition compared to resistance training alone. The study included 13 articles, with varying combinations of interventions yielding positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Older male adults with sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of vitamin D supplementation on VO2max and inflammatory status in vitamin D-deficient young men engaged in resistance training.
results_summary: The study found that 12-week vitamin D supplementation significantly increased serum vitamin D levels and improved inflammatory status but had no effect on VO2max in vitamin D-deficient young men performing resistance training.
population_specificity: Vitamin D-deficient young healthy men (baseline serum vitamin D level < 50 nmol/L)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether antioxidant vitamin supplementation (VitC and VitE) affects hypertrophic and functional adaptations to resistance training in trained men.
results_summary: Both groups showed similar improvements in strength metrics, but the placebo group had greater gains in upper body fat-free mass and handgrip strength. VitC/VitE supplementation appeared to blunt some hypertrophy adaptations but mitigated visceral fat gains from an energy surplus.
population_specificity: Trained men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and effect of an individually tailored exercise program, including resistance training, in older frail patients undergoing chemotherapy for colorectal cancer.
results_summary: Patients with high adherence (>50% attendance) showed significant improvements in physical tests after twelve weeks of exercise, while low adherence was attributed to lack of energy and treatment-related adverse events. No baseline differences were found between high and low adherence groups.
population_specificity: Older frail patients (≥70 years) receiving chemotherapy for colorectal cancer.
effective_dosage: Twice a week for 60 minutes per session, including progressive resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the temporal dynamics of muscular strength adaptations in resistance training and categorize studies under mechanical or metabolic stimuli to identify which stimuli cause faster muscle strength gains.
results_summary: The study found that the mean time point of first significant increase in muscle strength was 4.3 weeks, with an average increase of about 17%, and a plateau (~25%) occurred between weeks 8 and 12. Hypoxic training showed faster strength gains (~25% increase at ~2.8 weeks) but may risk imbalanced adaptation and injury.
population_specificity: 708 subjects from 57 training groups within 40 studies (general population, not specified further).
study_duration: Varied, with strength plateaus observed between 8-12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on resistance training for fall, fracture, and sarcopenia prevention in older adults, focusing on specificity, progressive overload principles, and potential effect modifiers like protein intake and creatine supplementation.
results_summary: Resistance training improves muscle mass, strength, and physical performance in older adults and may prevent bone loss, though its effectiveness for bone mass may require combination with impact exercise. Exercise programs, particularly those emphasizing balance and functional training, prevent falls, with resistance training recommended at 6-12 repetitions maximum intensity twice weekly.
population_specificity: Older adults
effective_dosage: Resistance training for major muscle groups at 6-12 repetitions maximum intensity, at least twice weekly

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of nutritional supplementation combined with resistance training on improving muscle mass and medical indices in inflammatory bowel disease patients with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that resistance training combined with whey protein significantly increased appendicular skeletal muscle mass and improved certain medical indices (albumin, hemoglobin, creatinine) compared to resistance training with placebo. No significant improvements were observed in other physical performance measures like grip strength or walk speed.
population_specificity: Inflammatory bowel disease patients with sarcopenia (n=28 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Resistance training 3 times a week; whey protein 10 g/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of protein supplementation combined with resistance training on muscle strength and functional performance in older adults.
results_summary: The study found mixed results regarding the benefits of protein supplementation for healthy older adults with adequate protein intake, suggesting no significant additional benefit. Further research is needed for specific subgroups like the very old, frail, or those with inadequate protein consumption.
population_specificity: Older adults, with potential focus on subgroups like the very old, frail, or obese.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of resistance training on glucose management markers in gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and discuss future research directions.
results_summary: Resistance training was effective in reducing insulin requirements (especially in overweight women), lowering fasting glucose concentrations, and improving short-term postprandial glycemic control. However, limited studies restrict conclusions on its impact on GDM risk, fasting insulin, insulin resistance, β-cell function, and intra-exercise glucose management.
population_specificity: Women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of creatine monohydrate (CrM) supplementation combined with strength and conditioning training on lower-limb strength and performance in young basketball players.
results_summary: CrM supplementation significantly improved lower-limb power and scoring performance in U16 basketball players, with notable increases in squat jump (SJ), drop jump (DJ), countermovement jump (CMJ), and ABK power compared to the control group. The results were statistically significant (P < 0.01) for all measured variables.
population_specificity: Male under-16 (U16) basketball players (age 14.3 ± 0.4 years, BMI 20.7 ± 2.2 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of graded versus constant protein intake combined with resistance training on muscle mass, peak torque, and muscle quality in older adults.
results_summary: Resistance training improved appendicular lean/soft tissue mass, peak torque, and muscle quality, but no differential effects were observed between graded and constant protein intake.
population_specificity: Older adults (n = 18)
effective_dosage: Constant protein (0.8−1.0 g/kg/d) or graded protein (0.8 g/kg/d progressing to 2.2 g/kg/d with whey protein supplement)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether protein supplementation combined with resistance training enhances lean body mass, muscle mass, and muscle strength in older adults compared to resistance training alone.
results_summary: Protein supplementation combined with resistance training led to greater increases in lean body mass and muscle mass but did not significantly improve muscle strength compared to resistance training alone. The quality of evidence ranged from moderate to very low.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining oral nutritional supplements with resistance training could minimize skeletal muscle atrophy in surgical patients after discharge.
results_summary: Resistance training combined with dietary supplements showed a greater increase in lean body mass (813 g) compared to diet alone (233 g) or control (78 g), though the difference was not statistically significant. The exercise and diet group also experienced a greater decline in pain scores compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Surgical patients aged 37–74 years, post-discharge, with malnutrition concerns.
effective_dosage: Resistance training sessions (frequency not specified) alongside a protein-rich oral nutritional supplement (22 g protein/day, twice daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of eight weeks of circuit resistance training and spirulina supplementation on weight, apelin, FBS levels, adipolin, and ghrelin in overweight and obese men.
results_summary: The study found significant changes in adipolin, ghrelin, weight, and FBS levels, with increased adipolin in the training groups. Apelin levels did not change significantly between groups.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese men (BMI > 25) aged 30-55 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of creatine supplementation combined with resistance training on aging muscle and bone, and its potential role in treating frailty and cachexia in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that creatine monohydrate supplementation, particularly when combined with resistance training, has favorable effects on aging muscle and bone, suggesting potential benefits for treating frailty and cachexia.
population_specificity: Older adults with sarcopenia or related conditions (e.g., frailty, cachexia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of six months of resistance training with or without nutritional supplementation on muscle thickness of the quadriceps in institutionalized older adults.
results_summary: Resistance training using elastic bands, with or without nutritional supplementation, did not alter muscle thickness of the quadriceps. However, participants with lower baseline muscle thickness or more diseases and medications showed significant increases in muscle thickness after the intervention.
population_specificity: Institutionalized older adults (mean age 82.6±6.2 years) in retirement care facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the current literature on the anti-inflammatory and anti-catabolic effects of creatine supplementation, particularly when combined with resistance training.
results_summary: The study found that creatine supplementation, especially when paired with resistance training, significantly increases muscle mass and strength, improves bone biology, and exhibits anti-inflammatory and anti-catabolic properties. It may also reduce muscle protein catabolism and bone resorption, particularly in males.
population_specificity: Various research populations (primarily males in some findings).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of intentional weight gain regimens, including resistance training, in promoting lean body mass in athletes.
results_summary: The study found that achieving a weekly weight gain of 0.45 kg (1 lb) as lean body mass may be difficult for some athletes, but strategies like calorie surplus, energy-dense foods, and liquid intake could help.
population_specificity: Athletes desiring weight gain

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically analyze the effect of carbohydrate intake on strength training performance across different conditions (acute supplementation, glycogen depletion, short-term, and long-term manipulation).
results_summary: Higher carbohydrate intake did not consistently improve strength training performance, except in specific conditions like fasted workouts with high volume (>10 sets per muscle group) or after glycogen depletion during bi-daily workouts. Long-term carbohydrate intake changes had minimal impact on performance.
population_specificity: Strength trainees or athletes (39 studies), recreationally active (6 studies), or untrained (4 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of resistance training in preventing and treating sarcopenia, particularly in cardiovascular disease (CVD) patients.
results_summary: Resistance training was recognized as an effective strategy to prevent and treat sarcopenia, though the abstract does not provide specific outcome metrics. The study also noted that dietary and antioxidant supplementation had limited evidence of efficacy for sarcopenia.
population_specificity: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) patients, particularly those at risk of sarcopenia and osteosarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity versus low-intensity resistance training (RT) on muscle strength in knee osteoarthritis (OA) patients and assess whether vitamin D supplementation enhances RT outcomes in vitamin D-deficient subgroups.
results_summary: High-intensity RT did not significantly improve isokinetic muscle strength, pain, or physical functioning compared to low-intensity RT, though it showed a slight advantage in estimated 1-RM. Vitamin D supplementation did not enhance muscle strength in deficient patients, but the study noted this finding was underpowered.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (mean age 67.6 ± 5.8 years), including a subgroup with vitamin D deficiency.
effective_dosage: RT at 70-80% or 40-50% of 1-RM; vitamin D3 at 1200 IU/day.
study_duration: 12 weeks of RT, 24 weeks of vitamin D/placebo supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether creatine supplementation combined with resistance training enhances muscle strength and mass in older females compared to resistance training alone.
results_summary: The study found that creatine supplementation combined with resistance training augmented gains in muscle strength and mass in older females compared to resistance training alone, though sex differences may influence effectiveness.
population_specificity: Older females with sarcopenia or age-related muscle loss.
